reviewText:
The Supreme Ruler series is one of the best grand strategy games you can find on Steam.

I started out with Supreme Ruler 2020 and played the hell out of it before and even after the Gold version came to Steam. With Supreme Ruler 1936 you not only get a better optimezed engine that can handle even more units and events than the previous one, but you get a time period that is extremely interesting to play in the Grand strategy scenario.

While the game might not look like much (graphics wise), it makes up for it with its superb and in-depth gameplay. You are the ruler of a nation, you take all the important decisions and even command your troops into battle as you take the territory of your enemy bit by bit.

What I like about this game compared to other Grand Strategy games is that while it is hex based, the style in which your units or the enemy units capture a territory is shown in a more interactive way making it feel like your actions truly have a great impact on the world.

The tech tree is also something to be amazed of, each tech you unlock as you progress through the years has a significant impact on the game and how you play the game and if you are able to survive the onslaught of enemies.

The economy is also complex and at times quite hard to manage, luckily the difficulty level can be adjusted to give new players an easier start on managing their resources. The buildings you can construct to help your economy range from simple wood managing complex to uranium mines. The economy also plays an important role on your armies, without petroleum your units will not move, without ammunition they will not fire, without construction materials you will not be able to build new structures and without food your population and army reservers will die.

The game is a must own to all Grand Strategy players, the game not only offers a singleplayer campaign and different skirmish / scenarios to play but also a multiplayer mode where you can fight with other players that control their own nations in real time.

reviewText:
This game is one of the most complex strategy games I've ever played. I mean, I needed 12 hrs. of playtime only for the Tutorial. *lol*

Supreme Ruler 1936 is a global political-warfare simulation that begins in early 1936 and can be played into the 2070s. Yes, the 2070s. That is when the tech tree runs out. You can literally start the game with biplanes, and end up fighting with Mechs. You have the ability to play as any major or minor power, with thousands of possible unit designs to select from. Complex economic system and technology tree. You can choose between 54 different countries in the sandbox modus. World Ruler with Liberia? No problem in this game. xD

Gameplay is fairly simple; it is basically a RTS (Real Time Strategy) game. Controls are standard for most RTS games—the ability to select large numbers of units at once, and other basic RTS controls. Furthermore, selections can be screened for specific unit types (air, naval or land) allowing for mass movement of forces. Land units are further divided in general categories—artillery, infantry, transport, armor, etc. Technology is fairly straightforward. Some can be traded or bought from other countries, while some have to be researched by each country individually and are non-tradable. Diplomacy is fairly detailed, with a wide variety of agreements possible, but given the scope of the game can be somewhat odd at times.

The combat system in SR36 is really the shining achievement of the game. “Chaos” perhaps describes it best—explosions, units advancing and retreating, the roar of naval gunfire, strafing aircraft, often at the same time. Units have detailed statistics outlining everything from their defense rating to weapons ranges.

Supreme Ruler 1936 is an unique game and if you like detailed warfare strategy games then try it out!

Axis and Allies the Board Game is better.   Wait what am I saying that game is awesome regardless.

I found at a Strategic Level the game is pretty well idiot proof.  Build Units, Click, Tell them to Point A or B and the AI just takes care of the rest.  This isn't much strategy outside trying to stay technologically a head of everyone else and planning a war not actually commanding and fighting a war.

It's just build armies, build up the economy, build factories, build more troops.

I found myself bored after conquering my first two countries.   I see this game would of been much better as a Turn Based Strategy game, but sadly even then there are already better games out there which are Turn Based.

Over all it's just pointlessly time consuming and not really all that entertaining.

Though on the Plus side, I did enjoy how you captured territories, it was slightly entertaining at first watching my armies fight, rooting them on as I tried to reinforcements to them in time.  But in general, it became quite old fast.

I may find myself revisiting this game later down the line when it's finished completely.   As it is in BETA still, but as it is now... it isn't worth spending money on in my opinion.

I was really looking forward to this game but having downloaded it two days ago I must say I am very very dispointed.

The game appears to be neither a strategic level (control the army/corps/whatever organisational unit) as the AI appears to do odd things (naval units appear to wander aimlessly around the map) and there is no ability to set up an organisational structure or introduce combined arms tactics, or a squad leader type game as units appear incapable of any type of real control authority.

Now you could say this is like real life, and I suppose to some extent it might be, but I don't want real life.  Its a game for goodness sake.  I want to feel in command, I want to organise my units as I see fit.  I want them to do as they are told (within reason).

If the game is pretending to be strategic, with the AI controlling individual units (and by the way nobody has as yet produced a computer based wargame that can cope adequately with the AI involved in such a demanding task) then let the player order divisions/corps around and let the AI try and do the unit grunt work ( and good luck with the outcome) or lets control the units and their deployment and play at unit level( then the AI is not so important.

As it is I find the game not only disapointing but very frustrating.

And please, please give us NATO symblos instead of the silly little cartoon type icons ( they suck), or at least a choice.

This purchase was money badly spent.  Don't buy this game.

reviewText: PROS: A decent economy model.   You build factories that supply both the consumer and military, anywhere from timber, coal, consumer goods, electricity, etc.  Supply works much better than in HOI3.  There is no shortage of units or unit types with no significant lag.  The game is easy to mod.  AI ministers can take over almost all aspects of the game, eliminating undesired micromangement.  The game has a lot going for it under the hood, most of it working well.  Battlegoat has a good reputation for supporting its games and the developers are active and involved with the community.\n\nCONS: No decent manual and inadequate explanations on how things work.  While the game isn't difficult to navigate, you suffer a lack of information about the technology trees (some techs are dead ends).   The sub war vs convoys isn't in the game.  The naval war takes a backseat to the land and air war.   Factory repair particularly with colonies is a complete mystery.  Faction balancing needs to be addressed particularly with Russia who seems to get beat up by Romania as ridicious as it sounds unless you start the 1940 campaign.  Gibraltar does not stop the Italian navy from leaving the Mediterraen as silly as that is.

reviewText: PROS: A decent economy model.   You build factories that supply both the consumer and military, anywhere from timber, coal, consumer goods, electricity, etc.  Supply works much better than in HOI3.  There is no shortage of units or unit types with no significant lag.  The game is easy to mod.  AI ministers can take over almost all aspects of the game, eliminating undesired micromangement.  The game has a lot going for it under the hood, most of it working well.  Battlegoat has a good reputation for supporting its games and the developers are active and involved with the community.\n\nCONS: No decent manual and inadequate explanations on how things work.  While the game isn't difficult to navigate, you suffer a lack of information about the technology trees (some techs are dead ends).   The sub war vs convoys isn't in the game.  The naval war takes a backseat to the land and air war.   Factory repair particularly with colonies is a complete mystery.  Faction balancing needs to be addressed particularly with Russia who seems to get beat up by Romania as ridicious as it sounds unless you start the 1940 campaign.  Gibraltar does not stop the Italian navy from leaving the Mediterraen as silly as that is.

reviewText:
Maybe its because I´m new to the Supreme-Ruler-series, but I cannot recommend this game. For long-time strategy players like me its just to arcade-like in its warfare part. But its easier to make a list anyway.

PROs
- the economic side is cool. You can built and reinforce your economic sectors in six categories and three manufactured goods. Plus you trade surplus and buy things you lack with ease.
- the builtup for war is easy. Units are built with land-/naval-/aircraft-factories in different cities. Plus you can hold them in reserve so they don´t clutter the map and cost immense resources
- I like the importance of recon units and the extra range of artillery. Makes the tactical combat fun.

CONs
- research is far reaching, but the easy way to trade it, destroys the fun. If you have researched the general tech, you can trade or buy unit-schemes from friends (or just anybody) for next to nothing. As Italy I ended up with advanced carriers of Japanese design and cool German recon units. Plus I think that there should be far more not tradeable research areas, so it´s more difficult to excel in research as a minor nation.
- producing units is very cheap, so you end up piling up units in reserve. which leads to:
- in my view your armies are far to vast to really control them properly in all theatres. So you end up losing small or prestigious units somewhere without even noticing it right away. Even units like carriers can be destroyed in seconds (which I did) or four submarine in a wolfpack are oblitarated in a glimpse. Its better in land and air combat, but naval combat just goes on to fast.
- the AI is not useless, but not very clever either. For example: As Germany attacked Poland the Western front to France was unguarded. Later it tried an invasion of Britain only with (zillions) of transports risking a good portion of its army. Fortunatly for Germany the British navy drove around aimlessly.
- the manual does not explain very much. So I looked in forums and learned much the hard way" via losing.

For me Supreme Ruler 1936 has many fun aspects
date: but it´s not properly balanced and too confusing in large scale combat. The AI is not clever enough to watch theatres for you (not mentioning your Allies) so you win mostly by sheer numbers."

reviewText:
First of all, the game is generally a good strategy game, eventhough there are several weak points.

I would like to point out some of the weaknesses that I think need attention:
1. The game is running too slow, though you have the option to change the time cycle, but it is still not significatly helping the game's time frame. When it is running slow, it can make you bored at some point.
2. You will find it hard to replenish or reinforce your current forces, as it takes a while to train and produce your war machines.
It will be better to shorten the time needed to produce a unit.
3. Battle could be pretty boring, since there is no option for you to have a detailed direct control of the units while battling the enemy.
4. Relationships between countries could be tricky to maintain and I could say that it is not historically correct. For those who prefer their own stories, then it does not really matter, but if you are looking for something that historically accurate, then the game should have an option for that.

In conclusion, the game is pretty good, though it has several weak points, but I still recommend this game to anyone who loves strategy game.

Developer please improve the game wherever possible! Thank you.

reviewText:
Though this game can probably be very enjoyable, in it's current state I don't recommend it to new players to the Supreme Ruler series.

Basic game mechanics are explained only superficially in a short tutorial. Understanding warfare, diplomacy, research and how to manage your economy and population will require you to wade through a wiki made for other games in the Supreme Ruler series, which isn't completely applicable to Supreme Ruler 1936. The Steam community luckily is helpful to a point, however a game company can't just leave the responsibility of getting to know the basics of a game to the community.

IMHO a game company delivers an incomplete product, when it doesn't give you an adequate manual or at least a decent tutorial with the full release of a game. This holds especially true for a complex game like Supreme Ruler 1936. Instead you are left to mostly figure the game out for yourself.
